newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: Mediation bid to end South African truckers' strike.
newsitem.headline: Mediation bid to end South African truckers' strike.

text.p: Mediation aimed at resolving a national trucking strike by around 36,000 workers across South Africa continued late into the night on Wednesday as negotiators sought to resolve a wage dispute.
"Mediation still going on," Transport and General Workers Union (TGWU) national organiser Thulani Dlamini told Reuters at about 10.20 p.m. on Wednesday.
The strike kicked off on Wednesday morning and spread to all sectors of the South African economy by the afternoon, said employer spokesman Johan van der Walt.

"The strike is widespread with some companies at a complete standstill while others are still running...it has affected sectors across-the-board," said van der Walt, who is chairman of the Road Freight Association.

Truckers went on strike after a last-minute attempt by the Commission for Conciliation, Mediation and Arbitration (CCMA) -- set up under the new Labour Relations Act -- to mediate failed on Tuesday night. The CCMA is a vehicle for dispute resolution that provides statutory dispute resolution services.
A TGWU spokesman said workers had originally demanded 14 to 18 percent across-the-board, but the union was seeking members' mandate on a 10 percent offer from employers.
Sectors of the economy affected by the strike include banking, air freight, waste companies, livestock vehicles, and the ferrying of chemicals and fuels.
This is the first time in 50 years that unions organised in the sector have resorted to industrial action.
